38720582.review:
Lemmings for a new generation.

The king wants the Holy Grail in order to gain eternal life, so he sends his knights out to get it. These knights have no talents beyond the ability to jump and total expendability. Over the course of the game, you will use the bodies of knights as stepping stones, wall grips, cannonballs, dead weights, and much, much more, in order to reach the magical cup at the end of the level, only to find that the cup cures tooth decay or mild stress or something equally minor, and have to go for another one. And another. And another.

The death toll is hideous, and it is hilarious.

38376680.review:
Loved the game, immediately got hooked for at least a week - pretty much spent all my free time on it until the physics got the better of me.

Positive:

1. Interesting and fun puzzles
2. Beautiful design
3. Hilarious jokes and entertaining tone of the game
4. There are several puzzles that deserve a separate mention as they are not only fun to play, but also present a nice logical challenge (this applies to the puzzles marked with a skull and to pretty much all puzzles in the Ruins location). Those complex puzzles were the most unforgettable moments of the game.

Negative:

1. Physics frustration: some puzzles rely heavily on physics, and not in a good way: for example, you can spend 15 minutes trying over and over again to jump the correct way, in a puzzle that needs to be solves in 40 seconds. Another annoying part is the ice cubes and the puzzles where you constantly need to make sure they don't slide away because they are so extremely slippery. I think this takes away from the game, because one hand it irritates the player and on the other hand you don't really get that sense of achievement when you overcome this kind of difficulty (i.e. "Yes! I finally managed to not let that ice cube slide away!"does not exactly give you the same sense of pride as "Yes! I finally solved this logical conundrum!").

2. Extremely, extremely difficult to get all the achievements, mostly for the reason above. I would have loved to get them all :(

38059410.review:
It's a puzzle platformer where dying leaves a body behind, which is actually a resource necessary to complete the level. For example, if there are floor spikes you can't get past, you can jump onto them and die, leaving behind a body that your next character can safely land on. Over the course of the game, the use of bodies gets increasingly creative, with buttons, conveyor belts, gravity beams, etc.

The game is well-made, and never gets overly difficult, instead opting to periodically introduce new mechanics. In addition, there are 3 bonus objectives on each level: finding a monster named Jeff, completing the level within a time limit, and dying a minimum number of times.

This is a deceptive little platformer/puzzle game.  It seems pretty easy at first piling minion corpses until you can litterally walk across the bodies to gain the prize.  But as the levels progress you're doing more and more horrible things to your valiant knights!  The combinations add up and, suddenly, you're franticly timing 3 differnet things at once to try to open the last gate only then realizing that the spawn point has moved!  When did that happen?  Now your knight is stuck instead of dead and you need to balance 3 more things to un-stuck him.  But as frustrating as it can get, it's so satisfying to finally get your brave knight Sir Percivil Horseradish to the final platform and collect the Grail of Minor Aches for our beloved king.

Much of the game you'll be going  "How the Hel....Oooooooooh."

The game is a fun diversion with a delightfully dark premise handled in a bright and comedic way.  Litterally advance on the backs of the fallen!

I guess the best way to describe this game is a puzzle of expendability. Meaning that most of your knights are of better use to you dead, than they are alive. For example you might need them as a mat over pikes, a deadweight on a button or a knightsicle to surf on in order to reach the golden cup. Oh, and don't forget to feed Jeff!!

You can decide to just have dumb fun with this game and slay your knights left right and centre (the supply is endless), or you can go try-hard and meet the time and lives spent callenges for every level.  In so doing you can unlock all kinds of hats and weaponry. Are these of any use in solving the puzzles? NO, none whatsoever! But at least you can send your knights to their deaths looking (slightly) cooler!

I picked this game up for half price during the summer sale, but I would have easily payed full price given the fun I've had with it sofar. It wasn't really that expensive to begin with. 
Life Goes On: Done To Death is an excellent choice for some casual gameplay if you have some time (and knights) to kill.

良作パズルゲーム。

小生はあまりパズルゲームは好きではないのですが、なんとなく面白そうな雰囲気で購入。
コントローラーで操作し、ボタンはジャンプボタン一つをいうシンプルさ。

決して忙しい操作や進行ではなく、一旦画面を見つめながら、頭の中でああだこうだと考えてからキャラを動かし始めるほどのまったりしたプレイです。

各ステージをクリアした時の達成感を、そこそこ毎ステージ味わわせてくれながら、たまに難しいステージに出会って進めず、その日は寝る。違う日にプレイすると、脳みそがリセットされ意外とサクっと進める。

グラフィックも綺麗で、キャラクター設定、ステージのシステム構成はユーモラスなセンスに溢れています。

パズルゲームがあまり好きでない小生が楽しめたので、このゲームに何かを感じる方は、プレイしてみてもいいんじゃないでしょうか。

35627138.review:
It's a puzzle game where you have to impale, burn, catapult, and generally sacrifice your previous characters (knights who have absurd titles and a growing array of hats and weapons) to get through the levels. 

Comedy is apparent throughout the entire game, from the weaponry/apparel your knights equip to the victory screen where the massive VICTORY that appears is enclosed by a much smaller font, condemning how that victory was achieved. 

The levels are innovative and novel, ranging from more basic can-find-it-in-every-puzzle-game layouts (which are mostly just near the beginning of the game while mechanics are still being introduced) to challenges that are wholly unique. Each level has a fuzzy monster (Jeff), and one of the challenges (the other two being time and killing as few knights as possible) is to feed one of your knights to Jeff. Sometimes, getting to Jeff can be harder than finishing the level (which is marked by getting to the cup found on each level). 

After finishing a level, you're able to see what the cup you achieved does (and it's all very inconsequential stuff, such as headache relief or something that harms rather than hurts, like a cup of strafe) The cups do nothing but to motivate the premise, which is the king of the knights is sending them to find the cup of life so that he may never die. They have to go through countless other cups first to find the cup of life. The [strike]plot[/strike] can easily be ignored while playing as it's really just there for context and atmosphere rather than having any impact on gameplay. 

The graphics are surprisingly good, and each set of levels has a unique look to them (the first set is in some mines, and all the levels have a certain feel to them while another set takes place in the mountains.) Each set, to assist in setting the atmosphere, has a unique soundtrack to go with it. While the overall soundtrack has many common themes, it distinguishes itself in each set to give a refreshing sense of [i]new[/i] to each set. Levels themselves are also distinguished from one another with each one posing a new challenge (especially the bonus levels, which are designed to be even more of a mind boggler than the usual ones.)

The game, overall, is lighthearted, hilarious, visually & audibly beautiful, and sometimes rather challenging. 

10/10, it's completely worth $13, and not buying it during the current sale is a veritable crime.

35047922.review:
[h1]Уморительный пазл-платформер[/h1]

Не стану описывать игру в лице "наследника леммингов", а поведаю об игре, как той, чем она является сама по себе.
Это, прежде всего, пазл. Головоломка во всей своей простоте. Пазлы не сложные, можно сказать даже, что очевидные, но игра делает одну правильную вещь - регулярно добавляет новые механики и прибавляет сложность по нарастающей.

Вы успеете влюбиться в игру ещё до первого подрыва вашей попки от непонимания как что-то решить.
А потом, внезапно, обнаружите, что помимо типичного пазла игра содержит ещё и чисто платформерские и экшеневые уровни, которые выполнены на твердую 5.

Проще говоря - игра не даст заскучать.
Она веселит, она озадачивает, она развлекает, она делает всё то, что должна делать любая игра - приносить удовольствие!

[h1]Кому стоит приобрести[/h1]
[list]
[*]Любителям пазлов без мозговыноса. Средней сложности и приятных механик игра~
[*]Шикарный юмор, развлекающий вас всем своим существом. Примерно так же, как это делает Team 17 для Worms, только ещё лучше. Отдельной похвалы заслуживают титры, наполненные самым различным стебом, к которому, как вам казалось, вы привыкли за время прохождения, но потом понимаете, что игре есть чем ещё вас... обломать ;)
[*]Искателям недорогих игр, которые окупили бы свою стоимость эмоциями и хорошим настроением (и не забываем: игра не новая уже, а значит скидончики-скидончики!)
[*]Хотите челенджа? Игра предоставляет их тем, кто захочет получить все ачивки. Вот тут попка-то и может погореть. Не хотите челенджа? Обещаю, вы получите удовольствие даже от простого казуального прохождения.
[/list]
[h1]Кому стоит воздержаться?[/h1]
[list]
[*]Большим ненавистникам игр без глубокой механики. Разнообразие механик не так велико, а управление вообще ограничено всего лишь WASD, и больше ничего не потребуется.
[*]Если вы не увлекаетесь Сеттингом, не любите наблюдать \ замечать нюансы в деталях, то, вероятнее всего, игра сама по себе и не представит ничего интересного из себя.
[/list]
[h1]Итог[/h1]
[list]
Life Goes On - во всех отношениях классный продукт. На него стоит обратить внимание тем, кто может и не любит особо пазлы даже, но любит игры вроде Portal, потому что в них присутствует некоторый шарм, обояние, а сами игры не обделены подачей своих сеттингов через историю и окружение.
[/list]
[list]
Если для вас атмосфера - не пустой звук, скорее всего вы полюбите подобную игру, даже если не увлекаетесь пазлами так, чтобы специально покупать игры подобного жанра (на собственном примере, господа).
[/list]
[h1]Оценка: [b]7.5+[/b][/h1]
[list][i]*лишь какого-то миллиметрового шажка не хватает, чтобы дотянуть до "А", но это вовсе не портит игру, скорее всего это даже проявление глубокого и подсознательного "хочу продолжения!"[/i][/list]

33963479.review:
One of the best puzzle-platformers I've ever played...and I've played quite a few.

Very polished, good puzzle difficulty (that ramps well), good platforming, lots of levels, lots of interesting mechanics (added naturally as you progress). The visuals are good, the death sounds are great, the music is good but pretty generic and repetitive. Finally, the humor is great, very sarcastic, grim, ironic. They put a lot of attention into the jokes everywhere they could squeeze them, and they're pretty much all good.

As a bonus, it works well both for relaxing, easy play where you just throw lives at it, as well as more intense play, trying to perfect the number of lives and the amount of time spent on each level.

My only complaint, really, is that some of the later levels felt like they were a few levels mashed together and could have been split up. And they're still fun and interesting, just long. I guess it doesn't hurt to mention that I also encountered a couple very minor bugs (mostly to do with activating some of the achievements), but they didn't affect my ability to play through the levels.

I would easily give it a 9/10

33937509.review:
Mein Fazit des Spiels gibt's unten, falls einem der ausführliche Text hier zu lang sein sollte, und man grob die Stärken und Schwächen des Spiels aufgelistet haben möchte.

[h1]Handlung[/h1]
Die Handlung von [i]Life Goes On: Done to Death[/i] ist, wie bei Puzzle-Platformern üblich, eher ein Mittel zum Zweck. Sie erzählt keine tiefe Geschichte, sondern gibt dem Spieler nur einen "Grund", all diese Rätsel zu lösen.
Ein König, der unsterblich sein will, sucht nach dem Kelch des Lebens. Das heißt, als König macht er sich natürlich nicht selbst die Hände schmutzig, sondern lässt [strike]sein entbehrliches Schlachtvieh[/strike] seine treuen Ritter nach ihm suchen.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
[i]Life Goes On: Done to Death[/i] hat ein innovatives und interessantes Gameplay. Wie in einem Platformer steuert man seinen Ritter auf der Suche nach dem Kelch des Lebens. [strike]Falls[/strike] Wenn der Ritter dabei das Zeitliche segnet, bekommt man einfach einen neuen hinterhergeschickt. Der Clou: Die Kadaver der gefallenen Ritter bleiben erhalten und sind das einzige Werkzeug zum Lösen der Rätsel. Diese Rätsel sind sehr vielseitig, aber immer zu bewältigen. Richtig knackig wird's erst, wenn man versucht, nicht nur in jedem Level die Vorgabe zu erfüllen, sondern auch alle Platinmedaillen zu bekommen. Die gibt's, wenn man in einem Level deutlich weniger Ritter geopfert hat, als angedacht war, sowie wenn man den Kelch besonders schnell gefunden hat. Auf diese Weise bietet das Spiel sowohl etwas für Einsteiger als auch für Hartgesottene. Zusätzlich gibt es in jedem Level ein pelziges Monster, was man füttern kann, aber was meistens schwierig zu erreichen ist. So wird aus jedem Level das meiste herausgeholt.

Die Steuerung funktioniert hier einwandfrei, was für diese Art von Spielen sehr wichtig ist. Die Befehle werden schnell umgesetzt und die Figuren steuern sich nicht träge. Allerdings empfehle ich hier die Steuerung über ein Gamepad, da die Steuerung über die Tastatur meines Erachtens nach ein wenig "kantig" anfühlen könnte.

[h1]Atmosphäre[/h1]
Optisch zeigt sich das Spiel in einer knuddeligen und bunten 3D-Grafik, die eigentlich im krassen Kontrast zu den gewaltsamen Toden der Ritter steht. Aber sobald ein neuer Ritter das Feld mit einer albernen Kopfbedeckung und einem total absurden Gegenstand anstelle einer Waffe betreten hat, vergisst man schon den Namen des tapferen Ritters, dessen knuffigen Todesschrei man eben noch vernahm, als man ihn an einer Wand aufgespießt hat, damit der nächste an ihm hochklettern kann.
Die Namen sind auch ein humorvolles Detail. Auf einer Schriftrolle am unteren Bildrand steht immer der Name des Ritters, den man gerade spielt. Ist der Ritter verstorben, wird der Name einfach durchgestrichen und der des nächsten Ritters darunter geschrieben. Dabei tragen sie schön mittelalterliche, teilweise schon total absurde Namen und Titel. (Ich sage nur "[b]Der Inakzeptable Edelmann Alf Hauer der Vierte[/b]").

Leider blieb der akustische Teil der Atmosphäre ein wenig auf der Strecke. Es gibt für jeden der vier Hauptspielabschnitte ein Musikstück, das dann auch in jedem Level des Abschnitts gespielt wird. Dabei wird man von der Musik eher berieselt, als dass sie einem auffällt. Fast keins der Stücke hat bei mir einen bleibenden Eindruck hinterlassen. Sie waren einfach da, aber ich könnte nach dem Spielen nicht sagen, welches Lied zu welchem Spielabschnitt gehört.

[h1]Schwächen[/h1]
Außer der eben erwähnten Schwäche im akustischen Bereich sind mir keine nennenswerten Schwächen aufgefallen.

[h1][u]Fazit / TL;DR[/u][/h1]
[i]Life Goes On: Done to Death[/i] ist ein innovativer Puzzle-Plattformer mit einem ziemlich schwarzem Humor, der mit der knuddeligen Optik des Spiels einen interessanten Kontrast bildet. Wer gerne Rätselspiele spielt und dem ein oder anderen skurrilen Element nicht abgeneigt ist, kann guten Gewissens einen Zehner investieren und dafür für mehrere Stunden unterhalten werden.

33752802.review:
The concept of dying strategically and using the bodies of your former lives to solve puzzles is a fresh and unique mechanic, but that's not the only thing that Life Goes On has to offer.

It is a charming and carefully crafted game, filled with humour and small details.

Life Goes On manages to convey both its entire story and its gameplay without a single word being spoken, and with only a few brief pieces of text to add flavour. The majority of the story is told by subtle gestures and small details, while the levels are carefully designed to explain each new mechanic in an intuitive manner without ever having to resort to a narrator or tutorial telling you what to do.

The game keeps slowly adding more mechanics over the course of its levels, making the levels become slowly more complex as you progress, but because of the careful way in which the mechanics are introduced and taught, the puzzles are challenging but never feel unfair or frustrating.

You can often win levels by throwing knights at them until you find a crude solution, but each level also has (optional) goals of body counts and time limits to hit.  For more challenge, it can be fun trying to work out how to reach the exact minimum number of deaths you need to complete each level.

I initially came across this game while browsing my discover queue during a Steam sale, and was immediately caught by the trailer video. 33524835.review:
超级丧病！超级魔性！论科学找死的技术哪家强！

一般的平台解谜，能不死就不死，哪怕再苟延残喘一刻都好。这游戏它不干！不仅要死，还要死出节奏，死出水平，在正确的时间和位置，果断自我了结。各种钉板、烈焰、电极、寒流、磁石，都需要按照一定顺序，找准时机，用一个个卖萌小骑士的性命去填坑，才能铺平前进的道路。最惨的是有些骑士死完还要被花样鞭尸，甚至连全尸都不留，简直毫（ting）无（bu）人（xia）性（lai）。强烈控诉国王[spoiler]其实就是玩家[/spoiler]的暴行！

游戏一共四大场景：矿坑、雪山、古堡、废墟，每个场景通常有15个左右的普通关、1个骷髅图标的附加关（比普通稍微烧脑一点），和1个boss关（地图更大，更杀人如麻）；工作人员表本身也是一个彩蛋关卡，加起来总计68关。

在难度的渐进性、谜题和操作的平衡性方面，本作表现非常棒，往往需要动一点脑筋，但绝不会难到解不出来，反之，也不会碰到明知解法却死活过不去的情况。对休闲玩家，多试两次总能通过，进阶之后，也有奖章挑战增加重玩性。对了，每一关别忘和毛球怪“成为好朋友”，这种友情特别珍贵~特别温暖人心~

游戏的奖章分为两种，其中，仁慈模式要求控制死亡人数，竞速模式自然追求最快完成。拿到金色奖章只是入门，上面还有一级紫色。

就个人感受，仁慈的紫色要比竞速好拿多了，记得当时前者进度已经八成多，后者才紫了五六个，有时比金色少40%的时间都不一定能升级为紫色。等到竞速全紫，差不多就有能力尝试一下【击败开发者】这项成就了，也就是一口气、不暂停、不跳关，用比开发者更短的总时间完成游戏。其它种种体现制作团队[strike]清奇脑洞[/strike]独特匠心的成就，在这边不做剧透，欢迎大家自行摸索。

仔细想想，国王为了寻找生命之杯，派出一队队骑士，寻找的代价却是无数人前赴后继，献出生命，不能不说是莫大的讽刺。经常有人说最好的喜剧是笑中带泪，用喜剧的外壳承载悲剧的内核。本作虽然没有太多演出，但通过寥寥几场动画、几句文字，能那么举重若轻地讲述一个本质悲怆的故事，不得不佩服制作者的黑色幽默。说明文字见缝插针的神吐槽也可谓锦上添花。

游戏过程中更是不乏用心的细节，比如墙上不起眼的一盏灯，关键时刻却能成为你的瞄准参考点；再比如，每个出场骑士不仅有名号和家系，甚至有专属的演员配音（尽管台词只有一句“啊——！”）。

之前有评论反馈本作配乐单调。确实，它不以音乐丰富见长，但好歹每一个新场景都会解锁新的变奏，个人还是蛮喜欢废墟部分的配乐的，让人免不了产生“啊，活着真好”的感慨[strike]，两秒后又心痛但毫不手软地干掉了一个[/strike]。

总之，除了坚定的萌物保护主义者，我想不出任何不给推荐的理由。向着圣杯冲啊——（卒）

Got this game on sale and it has proved to be thoroughly entertaining to play when bored.

Pros:
+ Lots of optional goals for players looking for a challenge.
+ Some puzzles have taken me over a few minutes to completely figure out (though this likely due to my own stupidity)
+ Graphic style is good
+ Constantly adds mechanics as the game progresses.
+ The game runs very well and loading screens are nowhere to be seen.
+ A whole variety of interesting, different puzzles.
+ Helped me realised that i cannot multitask.
+ Every level contains an adorable fuzzy monster that serves as an additional challenge (to reach and be murdered by).

Cons:
+ The physics system that this game frequently relies on may fail on you in an incredibly frustrating (and humourous) manner. (For example corpses getting stuck or moving/not moving when they should)
+ A few levels come across as repetetive, but you'll find this less as the game progresses.
+ The music may get on your nerves after a while.

It's good. And you get free hats.

33346721.review:
I bought this game and played for three hours straight before I started to loose attention. For this type of puzzle platformer, that's an excellent length of time to keep my focus. I'll probably load it up and do a few levels at a time until I'm all the way through, especially if it gets harder later on. 

The controls feel fair and responsive. I havent had any (unintentional) deaths where I feel like raging at the game for not doing what I told it to do. 

Introduction of new game mechanics and play techniques seems well-paced so far. 

Level design is excellent, although possibly a bit too easy at times.

Graphics are functional. The style is nice, but the actual scenery and models look a bit dated, even considering the age of the game. There's a good variety of scenery, and some nice hand-drawn UI maps between levels.

32964340.review: В далеком уже 1991 году появились на свет Lemmings, предложившие необычную концепцию - ценой жизни меньшинства перевести большинство из точки А в точку Б. С той поры идея получила несколько продолжений и множество вариаций, изменяясь, обрастая подробностями и вообще эволюционируя. Но ядро осталось прежним - дойти по трупам до конца. Life Goes On тоже, в каком-то смысле, эксплуатирует эту идею. У нас есть преданные делу до последней капли крови рыцари, которыми надо добраться до определенной точки. Разумеется, присутствует богатый арсенал смртоносных предметов, и даже (спойлер!) и сама Смерть. По сути, всю игру мы и занимаемся тем, что решаем, как убить персонажа так, чтобы следующий смог пройти немного дальше и, в свою очередь, умереть там. Получилось весело, с шутками и прибаутками, местами очень непросто, но проходимо. В общем, отличная игра.

Great game. Overall, I'd give it a solid 8.5/10.

The puzzles are actually challenging. Not to mention I absolutely adore the core mechanic (I mean, who heard of a game where you HAVE to die?!?); truly unique stuff. The puzzles require some thought, and you have multiple metrics on which you are graded, significantly increasing the replayability. Additionally, the game maintains an light, humorus tone (which is particually important, because if you mishandle the aesthetics on a game about killing yourself then it takes a dark turn mighty fast).

Honestly, I don't see much room for improvement. I rate at an 8.5 because I reserve anything higher than that for games which take my breath away/bring a tear to my eye/engage me for a long time, and by design this just isn't one of those games. Not a complaint as much as an explanation.

Kudos to the devs for making me laugh while I killed myself 10 times over.

31488948.review:
[b]You might like if:[/b] You want a charming puzzle platformer that makes you smile as much as it makes you think.

A game that lives up to its wonderful trailer! (The music had me hooked)

Not the biggest head-scratcher out there (though later puzzles can still take a good 10 minutes to suss)... but that's not the real joy of Life Goes On. This is a game that ultimately has a simple concept, but delivers big. You basically have to get to the chalice within the level, but the catch is that you have to sacrifice your knights in order to do so. Want to get across that long chasm? Freeze your comrade and use them as a skateboard to fly over it in style... you get the idea.

The real joy of the game is that it doesn't rely on a simple novel concept to prop it up. The game is [i]full[/i] of fun... whether it's the dry remarks on the victory screen, the funny weapon descriptions or the names of the chalices that are [i]not[/i] the cup of life. The music's gorgeous, the slapstick sound effects still make me chuckle and the graphics, though simple, are clean, quaint and fun.

What's particularly nice is how the game operates at many levels to cater for casual to hardened puzzlers. Completing a level is one thing... but can do you it in good time with a limited number of deaths? How about the side-challenge each level has? These extra challenges unlock more goodies but are also "good enough" targets. For those who want more... there's a hidden level above this: A [i]perfect[/i] time or number of deaths (subtly indicated by a purple badge). It doesn't wave it in your face or tell you what score you need, so doesn't berate players who don't care for perfection... but is there if you want it! This subtlety creates a brilliant next step to the puzzles, as you're replaying and trying hard to find where you can make efficiencies and spare the odd knight here and there. But where you don't know how many you need to get... it, in itself, becomes a new puzzle!

But they're not mandatory. Players can freely skip these without missing out on any of the fun content, so the perfect challenges are only really there for those who [i]actually[/i] want to go for them (e.g. I don't bother with the perfect times). A very subtle, but clever, move by the developers.

Ultimately, when you die in most other platformers, you can hear the game taunting you as it hauls you back to the last checkpoint and makes you do it all over again... but here, it hands you a cookies and says "ah that's ok... say, your dead friend looks like a great stepping stone!" - It's playfully morbid and, even if you're doing terribly, you can't help but smile weakly as the piles of bodies just build up. It's playful, engaging and has delivered a hearty collection of fun puzzles.

Not the flashiest title, but certainly one of the more charming.

31482740.review: Hra je velmi kvalitně zpracovaná. Vypadá nádherně, úrovně jsou dobře navržené, vše funguje bezchybně a především je to zábavné. 31455670.review:
"If I have reached further than others, it is because I stood on the shoulders of giants." If Netwon had played this game, the giants would be the bodies of your dead comrades.

In this game, you control an army of knights in desperate search for the Cup of Life. However, it's a dangerous journey and many will die along the way. Fortunately, each knight has a better chance than the one before; not only because you've learned from his sacrifice, but because his body is now a helpful platform on top of those spikes, or is completing an electrical circuit to open that door, or is just enough a stool to help you reach that ledge. Jump, push, and die your way through 4 worlds full of puzzle-filled levels, leaving a huge body count in your wake.

It's one of the most hilariously fun puzzle platformers I've ever played. Its gimmick seems like it would get old very quickly, but they keep finding new ways to keep it fresh and introduce new challenges. It's puzzles can be a bit on the easy side if you're a veteren at puzzle games, but the notion of having to die to progress adds a perspective of puzzle-solving not often seen in other games.

All in all, it's a blast. A must-buy for platformer fans.

30615741.review:
Un jeu de puzzle bien equilibré, avec une difficulté croissante, et des tableaux simples presentant a chaque fois les mecaniques de gameplay s'implementant au fur et a mesure.

En plus de la solution de l'enigme a chaque tableau, 3 objectifs facultatif (le temps le nombre de chevalier "gaspillé" et la decouverte de la mascote)sont possible, ce  qui amene a deux constatations :
- le jeu ne presentant pas une difficulté elephantesque, il n'y a pas de frustration de blocage sur un tableau 
- la difficulté est volontaire, soit je passe a l'enigme suivante, soit j'essaye de faire le temps objectif , de nourrir la creature ou de sacrifié moins de chevalier.
Beaucoup de jeux presentent leurs enigmes ainsi, avec des objectifs secondaires que l'on appellerai maintenant "newgameplus", mais a contrario des autres, comme la progression est constante dans "Life Goes On: Done to Death"et l'arrache de cheveux inexistant dans ce jeu, il est bien plus engageant de recommencer un niveau en pofinant sa methode ou sa strategie d'approche.

un bon divertissement pour un petit prix

30051680.review:
Что такое неизбежное самопожертвование? Это "Life Goes On: Done to Death" ! Но не спешите: надо постараться, чтобы умереть изощренным способом, и помочь последователям... тоже умереть, но немного позже и ближе к цели. Дисковые пилы, огнеметы, шипы... а также великолепный Семен помогут в этом.

Игра представляет головоломку, обильно приправленную черным юмором. Взаимодействуя с различными механизмами, на каждом уровне требуется завладеть золотой чашей. Уровни продуманы и имеют дополнительные задачи: опередить заданное время, потерять меньше жизней и накормить Семена. На некоторых уровнях от игрока требуется еще и высокая скорость при выполнении определенной последовательности действий.

Русская локализация выполнена аккуратно. Пусть переводить особо нечего, но есть веселые титры и комиксы. Около половины достижений получить вполне реально при первом прохождении. За некоторые из остальных придется бороться с фанатизмом. Так что игра не для легкого попадания в список идеальных.

Не могу назвать серьезных минусов. Продукт выглядит завершенным: графика, музыка, отлаженные механизмы уровней, локализация... Разработчики постарались (на что ушло, по их словам, четыре года).

Рекомендую откликнуться на призыв Короля и помочь ему найти заветную Чашу Жизни :-)

29434016.review:
Imagine a kingdom of valiant knights, duty bound in their service to a cruel king. A king who does not mind electrocuting, impaling, burning or freezing them to find the cup of life his heart is yearning for. In fact he does not even mind sacrificing them to find a cup that might or might not, but likely not, be the cup of life. Not even when he is using his knights as ammunition in a cannon (insert cannon fodder pun here). 

And now imagine that you are this king.

This is a really fun puzzle game. I am a bit reminded of lemmings, even though those two are still very distinct (among other things the goal of lemmings was to keep most of them alife, whereas here you sacrifice as many as needed to get one to the goal).

And if you get it at a discount... there's really nothing you can do wrong there.

Life Goes On ist ein perfektes Spiel für zwischendurch. 

Die Rätsel fangen sehr simpel an und steigern sich dann aber bis hin zu wahren Knobel-Aufgaben, ohne jedoch zu frustrieren. In vielen Levels kommt man durch beobachten und logisches Denken schnell auf die Lösung, aber selbst wenn es mal schwerer wird - probieren geht über studieren. Und ganau das macht dann auch schlicht und einfach mehr Spaß. Die einfallsreichen und schier endlosen Möglichkeiten, seine Ritter in den Tod zu schicken um an das eigentliche Ziel zu gelangen werden nicht langweilig :D

Für Freunde von Rätsel-Spielen (und vielleicht auch einer leicht sadistischen Ader xD ) absolut zu empfehlen. 
Und auch wenn es eher kurzweilig ist, für den Preis im Sale (3.39 Euro) durchaus lohnenswert.

这是一个欢乐向的机关解谜游戏，玩家要做的是操纵一个又一个骑士触碰机关，把他们冻成冰块、当作弹药、搭成人梯……

每个关卡有限时和限死挑战，只要找到通关的方法就可以轻松达到要求，完成挑战后还没发现有什么好处，也许牵涉到成就。

部分关卡有一只名为JEFF的毛球生物，对其喂食后可以解锁新装备，装备没有任何附加功能，只是让骑士”长“得不一样，可能也和成就有关。

听说游戏流程不长，不推荐原价入，感兴趣的可以等打折。

"Po tru­pach pędzisz do ce­lu... 
ze swoim dążeniem zos­ta­niesz sam jak pa­lec przyjacielu.
Wszys­tko co osiągniesz ka­mieniem się stanie
przy­wali cię - i nikt z po­mocą przy to­bie nie stanie..." - bosy
             *in­spi­rowa­ne myślą Fargo 

Life Goes On: Done to Death, kanadyjskiego studia Infinite Monkeys Entertainment Ltd., to wydana w 2014 roku gra przygodowo-zręcznościowa z elementami logicznymi. Hisoria opowiada o tym, jak pewien król zapragnął zdobyć magiczny kielich, który daje życie wieczne. Wysyła on, na wyprawę, swoich najdzielniejszych rycerzy. Jednak, aby się tam dostać, na wielu śmiałków czeka nieunikniona śmierć, bo bez niej nie dałoby rady zajść dalej. Mapa dzieli się na 4 etapy, w których każdy charakteryzuje się unikatową scenerią. np. góry, czy zamek. Pokonując kolejno poziomy, natrafiamy na coraz to trudniejsze zagadki. Pułapek jest dużo, przykładowo kolce wystające z ziemi, miotacz płomieni, czy urządzenie emitujące prąd elektryczny. Przechodząc poziomy, zdobywamy kolejno nowe elementy ubioru naszych śmiałków, czapka świętego Mikołaja, hełm Wikingów, czy gogle na oczy, to tylko niektóre z nich.
W Life Goes On: Done to Death, śmierć jest naszym nieodzownym elementem rozgrywki.

Life Goes On: Done to Death to bardzo dobra gra logiczna. Muzyka piękna, wręcz na wysokim pioziomie. Przy niektórych poziomach, potrafiłem spędzić naprawdę, naprawdę dużo czasu, główkując jak rozwiązać daną zagadkę. Lecz się nie poddawałem i próbowałem sprostać bliżej nieokreślonym zadaniom.

Ogólna ocena gry: 6

Do you believe in casual cruelty? 
Do you believe in murder and death for the sake of honestly rather pointless goals?
Do you enjoy the screams of your knights as they sacrifice themselves to your will?

Of course you do! 

This amusing game centers around using the dead to help the living move forward. Often with their corpses. 
There's the joy of carefully thinking through your path in order to sacrifice as few as possible, making use of timing and skills to avoid needless casualties. 
There's also the joy of having a carpet of freshly dead bodies to safely and leisurely walk on as you make your way to the end. 

Don't forget that murder is fun!

This is an amazingly addictive puzzle/platformer. Using the corpses of your previous characters to solve the puzzles is both hilarious and an interesting mechanic. The levels are challenging without being frustrating, and the difficulty curve is resonable. Optional goals such as using the fewest possible number of knights really adds to the replayability. 

I nominated this game for the "I thought this game was cool before it won an award" award because it's one of one of the most fun and interesting indie games I've played in a while. Overall it's a ridiculous game with an interesting mechanic, a great sense of humor, nice art, an enjoyable soundtrack, and Jeff.

26139704.review:
I bought this because it was cheap and looked like a good game for when I'm in the mood to play something more casual. I was surprised by how fun this game got with each new level and each new mechanic. The gameplay is very addictive and simple yet tons of fun and thoughtful.The pacing is great as each level offers carefully constructed puzzles that feel fresh rather then copied or repeated. As you get used to encountering a trap or puzzle mechanic the game adds new layers to keep you thinking!

l*] The game is plain fun. Not a single complaint about it. The gameplay is solid and feels rewarding as you solve silly puzzles by sacrificing your oddly named loyal knights.

[*] The audio is pleasant, no annoying soundtrack or repetitive horrible sound effects that drive you insane.

[*] The visual style and graphics suit the game completely and are quite delightful. 

[*] Appeals to casual gamers as well as those looking for a challenge as each level can be replayed with several objectives to try and accomplish including finding secrets, beating a level with the fewest 'lives' sacrificed and speed running. Completing all challenges for each level and earning the highest score/award can be quite challenging even for a hardcore gamer- but these objectives are all optional and are NOT required to continue to the next level. 

[*] The length of the game so far is quite a bit more then I originally expected. After 3 hours I don't think I'm even at the half way point yet- I might be nowhere near it! 

[*]In my 3 hours I've expirienced no stutter, long loading times, bugs, glitches or any annoyances. The game has run quickly and smoothly throughout, and I'm playing it at it's highest settings on a fairly cheap laptop that can't run AAA games.

I would recommend this game to anyone who wants a game that can be played in short bursts or longer sessions, anyone looking for something non-serious and affordable.

24677451.review:
Eines der besten Puzzle-Spiele die ich je gespielt habe.
+ Interessantes Spielprinzip:
+ Knifflige Rätsel, die Schwierigkeit steigt langsam an und es kommen immer wieder neue Elemente/Spielmechaniken hinzu.
+ Alles lösbar, aber man braucht schon mal ein paar Versuche. Wo hat sich nur Jeff schon wieder versteckt? Wie schafft man das bloß ohne so viele Ritter zu braten?
+ Tolles Level-Design, witzige Waffen und Hüte, man gewinnt die Ritter einfach lieb (und dann schickt man sie leider in den Tod :D) 
Alles in allem macht das Spiel einfach Spaß und fordert dabei die grauen Zellen ein wenig (oder auch mal mehr). 
Was leider auch keine Selbstverständlichkeit ist: Sehr gute Qualität (keine Bugs bemerkt, wirkt nicht unfertig), ich kenne die alte Version nicht aber Done to Death macht einen durchaus "runden" eindruck.

Ich kann "Life Goes On" nur weiterempfehlen, wer Rätselspiele und etwas morbiden Humor mag ist damit sehr gut bedient.

Spieldauer: Erster Durchgang etwa 9 Stunden, aber es werden noch einige mehr, bis alle Level in den Vorgaben sind und Jeff endlich satt ist.

24228304.review: This game involves using your own death in various ways to overcome puzzles. It invludes laying down on spikes to create a death walkway, opening switches,getting flung from a cannon ball to open more switches,being a zombie. It is just like having any number of alternative selfs who could do button pushing for you. It is not something new but the death mechanic in the way of doing things I think is never been done before. the puzzles are pretty simple and you can breeze through the same as each level as subcheckpoints. The checkpoint system is itself unique in the way that it spawns you there after you did and that is used in many puzzles asa mechanic. Overall a good game if played in bursts. [h1]Life Goes On: Done to Death est un jeu de plateformes passionnant et même plus[/h1]

Vous jouez un Roi... bon, disons le carrément, un despote. Vous envoyez vos chevaliers vers une mort certaine pour récupérer des coupes magiques. Quand vous aurez obtenu toutes les coupes, vous devriez trouver le moyen d’atteindre l’immortalité... sur la mort de vos chevaliers !

Pour atteindre certaines plateformes, pour passer certains précipices, pour déclencher certains interrupteurs, il est nécessaire qu’un ou plusieurs chevaliers fassent don de leur vie. Ils permettent ainsi aux chevaliers suivants de passer la zone difficile et ainsi atteindre la coupe.

23653950.review:
自らの命を省みず、ただひたすらに聖杯を求めて……だーいだいだい、大勝利！！！

良い点
・設定が斬新！（仲間の死体を足場に進みます）
・カジュアル層向け、適度な難易度（よく見かける”後半はパズルマニアのみしかクリア不可”のようなゲームではない）
・やりこみが豊富（単純にクリアするだけでなく、規定の時間・死亡数・ジェフ食を満たす・特定マップの高難易度実績もあり）
・超優秀な公式日本語訳（「フワフワで良い匂いのする安全な死の床」「反社会的なマンリー卿」「ここで王に抗おうものなら、結構気まずくなる」）
・飽きさせないギミック（同じ作業の繰り返しはありません！　常に新しい発想が必要。　雪山ステージのラストマップやクレジットなど爆笑必至のマップも）

悪い点
・パズルゲームにしては要求スペック高（手持ちの古いノートPCではオプションの設定で"処理を優先"にしないと画面がバグって遊べませんでした、でも処理落ちは無し）

王様の命令により命の聖杯探しの旅に出た騎士くんたちの物語。
ゲーム内容は公式PVを見ましょう。どんなゲームかよく分かります。
1マップの長さも悩みぬいて１０分以内、詰む事もほぼ無い、空いた時間にふと気が向けば楽しめる、まさに暇つぶしに最適なゲームです。
値段もかなり低いため、気になるようであればウィッシュリスト、セールなら即買いでも損はしない面白さを保証します！（個人によります）
参考までに、クリアまで12時間で3000人の犠牲者が！　これは……大目に見ても、大勝利！！！

23426677.review:
Jeu de plateformes/puzzles (mais surtout de puzzles) dans la lignée de The Swapper, mais en plus rigolo... et en un petit peu plus difficile, notamment suite à la dernière mise à jour qui a rajouté un niveau assez costaud.
N'étant ni une flèche, ni une lumière, je l'ai terminé en douze heures.
 
Un peu comme chez les politicards, le jeu consiste à marcher sur le corps de ces prédécesseurs pour arriver à ses fins.
En effet, ici, la mort n'est pas punitive mais utile et conseillée. Qu'il s'agisse de franchir une fosse hérissée de pics, de peser avec votre cadavre sur un bouton (le jeu utilise beaucoup la physique), de servir de boulet de canon ou de servir de conducteur à du 220 volts pour ouvrir une porte, vous devrez bien souvent vous sacrifier pour que le suivant puisse avancer dans le casse-tête, et ce avant qu'il ne doive lui-même mourir à son tour... Il n'y a pas de limite au massacre, si ce n'est l'envie d'économiser les vies pour faire un bon score, si possible en un minimum de temps.
 
Le but du jeu est de conduire (et de sacrifier) de petits chevaliers jusqu'à leur Graal. Le jeu est divisé en quatre niveaux, eux mêmes divisés en puzzles indépendants. Il y en a soixante-cinq en tout... et donc autant de Graal. On progresse sur une carte qui raconte un semblant d'histoire façon parchemin en débloquant les tableaux les uns après les autres. Libre au joueur de recommencer un puzzle s'il en a envie pour améliorer son score. Des bonus cosmétiques (chapeaux et épées fantaisie) récompensent la résolution ou un bon score. On peut aussi essayer de "nourrir" avec un chevalier une petite boule de poils dissimulée dans le décor pour se rajouter un challenge supplémentaire.
 
La difficulté est bien foutue car elle est très progressive. Si le début est très facile, les puzzles du dernier niveau, celui de la cité dans les nuages, m'ont vraiment donné du fil à retordre. Car les mécaniques s'accumulent. Si on commence avec de simples embrochages sur des panneaux ou des lits de pics, on en vient bientôt à devoir gérer des portails de réapparition, des interrupteurs électriques, d'autres qui nous obligent à rester en vie, des cubes de glaces contenant nos cadavres, des portails de téléportation, des canons, des modificateurs de gravité et même des doubles zombifiés. De quoi se creuser les méninges !
 
Mais ça n'en reste pas moins un jeu très agréable qui dispense son humour noir de manière légère et potache. On notera également un petite référence à Portal dans un des puzzles.
Si graphiquement on atteint pas des sommets, ça reste mignon et agréable à regarder, et puis les petits chevaliers sont sympas. La musique est pas mal du tout et accompagne bien le mélange épique et bon enfant de l'aventure.
Personnellement, j'ai beaucoup aimé y jouer et je le conseille à toute personne qui aime les puzzles et les jeux de réflexion.
 
Les plus :
 
- un principe (l'obligation de mourir) et des puzzles sympas
- une bonne progression dans la difficulté
- beaucoup d'humour... jusque dans les crédits de fin
- une maniabilité au poil au clavier (pourtant j'ai deux mains gauches)
- c'est mignon comme tout
 
Je ne trouve pas de "moins" à signaler et je ne vais pas en mettre pour en mettre.
Un jeu aux ambitions modestes mais qui remplit parfaitement son cahier des charges.

23273753.review:
Eine Spielempfehlung an alle hochwohlgeborenen Lordschaften da draußen, die den einen oder anderen lästigen Untertanen loswerden wollen: Schickt sie auf eine Expedition nach dem Kelch des Lebens.

Je weiter man im Spiel vorankommt, desto schwieriger, größer und komplexer werden die Level. Die immer neuen Instrumente, wie Flammenwerfer, Kanonen, stachelige Laufbänder, Antigravitationsfelder, und weitere Spielarten des kurzweiligen Entsorgens von Lakaien, werden zuerst in eingängigen Zusammenhängen dargestellt, bevor sie in größeren Schauplätzen eine Rolle spielen; das Spiel ist selbsterklärend - mit ein oder zwei Minions geht probieren über studieren.

Schätzt man die Herausforderung, kann man auch versuchen, die vorgegebene Anzahl an verschlissenen Rittern zu unterbieten oder schneller als die Uhr zu sein. Und wer dann immer noch nicht genug hat, kann seinen Hirnschmalz darauf verwenden, eine der Blechbüchsen durch das Rätsel zu Jeff zu geleiten (ein Chewbacca in rund) und die wandelnde Rüstung in seinen kleinen gierigen Rachen zu stopfen.

Ich habe sowohl aufgrund von spontanen Anfällen der Genialität gejubelt, bin an schier unlösbaren Rätseln verzweifelt und habe mich höchstpersönlich weggeschmissen, wenn der letzte erfolgreiche Ritter von einer Flut aus verbrauchten Kollegen begraben wurde.

Obwohl die Minions eigentlich alle gleich aussehen und nichts weiter als hohle Blechbüchsen sind, wurden sie doch so liebenswert designed und animiert - sie haben sogar jeder einen eigenen Namen!, dass man sich wie ein Sadist vorkommt, wenn ein Ritter zuviel aus Ungeschicklichkeit in der stacheligen Grube gelandet ist.

Die Credits ganz am Ende setzen dieser Kurzweil - ha  ha - die Krone auf.

23032107.review:
Life Goes On is one of those games where a small, simple concept really carries the game through the whole experience. The idea that you need to die to use your own corpse to get through a puzzle is really cool. Most of the puzzles force you plan a few steps ahead to strategically die in one spot to use that corpse later. The puzzles hit a sweet spot where they're not so tough that they leave you crying in frustration, but are hard enough that you'll need a few tries to see the solution, giving you a solid sense of satisfaction when you do solve it.

The game has a lot of charm and great sense of humour. It's pretty self-aware of how morbid it's core concept is and takes more than a little delight in punishing the main characters over and over again. I laughed out loud a couple of times. 

Most players will finish the game in a single night, which is fair value for the price. I like games in which you can have a full experience in a single sitting. In that sense it reminds me of Thomas was Alone and similar indies. Each level has extras challenges and a target number of deaths needed to get to the end. I found myself replaying levels to try different tactics to avoid piling up bodies as a brute force solution to a puzzle. 

The only complaint I have is that jumping feels a little loose at times. There's a particular sequence with ice blocks that I felt held me up because I had trouble sticking my jumps, not because I hadn't solved the puzzle. Beyond that, it also feels like the game shows you most of its ideas around 75% of the way through. Even so, I suggest sticking it through to the end because the final level for each world is epic and a great example of using level design to tell a story.

23030359.review: "Life Goes On" is an inventive, charming, morbid, and challenging game. If you like having your ingrained habits turned upside down, this game is for you. I felt very similar to the way I felt when learning to play Braid. It forces you to think about your character's impact on the world in completely new ways. Am I a monster for throwing away the lives of loyal knights like used tissues? Yes. Am I having lots of fun doing it? Darn right. Get this game.

22543091.review:
This game is a fun little physics based puzzle game that has you valiantly send brave knights to their deaths so that they can help the next knights solve the puzzle!

Basic game premise is that you need to retrieve the golden chalice on the level while avoiding the various hazards. Thing is, the hazards typically require you to kill one of your knights in a creative way so that a future knight can take advantage and proceed further along on the puzzle.  Mix in a twist of some dark humor and it's a fun experience that is easy to play in brief or longer sessions.

It also provides additional challenge modes such as completing with fewest deaths in certain amount of time to add some replayability.

It's morbidly hilarious at times with some good puzzle progression to get you thinking about how to use mechanics culiminating in some interesting and well designed puzzles by the end!

If you don't like puzzle games at all, you're not likely to enjoy this game. If you do like puzzles (or at least open to the idea) then read on! The difficulty of the puzzles ramps up nicely so you'll likely find some challenges in later levels, but not overly frustrating ones. The game also provides achievements beyond just finishing the levels, for those wanting more brain teasing. And the game just oozes charm, with its cartoonish knights (taking some of sting out of what is actually a pretty macabre game... a dark sense of humor may help) and death traps. One of my favorite things is the roster of, often silly, names at the bottom that get steadily crossed out as you kill more of your knights.

It has an expansion coming too, which likely means I'll be revisitng the game myself soon. Thumbs up!

そんなタイトルのゲームがありましたが、こちらもソレを地で行く感じの面クリア型のパズルアクションゲームです。
というか、むしろ死体を積極的に利用しないとクリア出来ないです。
アクションゲームですが、アクションよりパズル要素の方が強いのであまりアクションが得意でなくてもパズルが得意なら先に進められると思います。
個人的には砲台が苦手でしたが、試行錯誤すればどうにかなるのでじっくり取り組めばクリア出来ると思います。
クリアするだけなら死ぬ回数は気にしなくてもいいですし。

一番気に入っているのは最終面です。
是非、最後まで面を進めて見て欲しいです。最終面に来るまでに自分はサクサククリア出来なくて結構イライラしてしまいましたが、最後まで来て笑ってゲームを終えることが出来ました。
日本語化もされていますしオススメです。

あと、自分のPCの問題かもしれませんが、毎回言語設定が英語に戻ってしまう不具合がありました。起動するたびに日本語に戻してプレイするのが少し面倒でした。
他にバグやクラッシュもなくそういう点に於いても良かったです。

17244481.review:
똑같은 외양의 '기사'들의 희생을 통해 스테이지를 클리어하는 플래포머 게임.
'나의 시체를 넘어서 가라.' 라는 말이 가장 잘 어울리는 게임이다.

먼저 조종하는 기사를 통해 자기 한 몸 희생하여 나중에 조종할 기사들을 위한 발판을 만들어주거나 자기 한 몸이 블록이 되거나 특정 장치를 작동시켜준다. 그리고 나중에 조종하는 기사들은 앞서 자기 한 몸 희생했던 기사의 움직임을 바탕으로 더 앞으로 나아가게 된다. 예를 들자면, 바닥에 가시가 넓게 깔린 지형은 기사가 자신을 가시에 투신하여 자신의 몸이 나중에 조종할 기사들에게 가시를 무사히 지나갈 수 있게끔 발판의 역할을 해 주는 것이다. '희생'이라는 컨셉을 잘 살렸으며, 삶은 지속된다는 게임의 제목과도 묘하게 연결된다.

이 기전을 통한 게임의 레벨 디자인이 상당히 신선하다. 다양한 장치가 준비되어 있고 그것들이 다양한 방식으로 배치가 되어있어 머리쓰는 맛은 좋다. 물론 그만큼 게임이 어렵다는 말이기도 하다. 특히나 최소한 적은 숫자의 기사를 희생하고 최대한 빠른 시간 안에 클리어하면 골드/퍼플 레이팅이 주어지게 되는데, 이것들을 노리기 위해선 훨씬 골머리를 싸매야 한다. 대체로 스테이지들이 짧은 편이긴 하지만, 클리어를 위해 고민하는 시간은 결코 짧지 않을 게임이다.

조작이 생각보다 잘 안되는 느낌을 받았다. 특히나 희생된 기사의 몸을 발판으로 활용할 때 심각하게 드러나는 단점인데, 기사의 몸뚱이란게 통나무마냥 통짜가 아니다보니 기사들을 발판삼아 밟거나 기대고 있자면 미끄러지는 상황이 꽤 발생한다. 희생된 기사의 시체를 활용할 때도 마찬가지인데, 반드시 되야 할 상황에서 이상하게 뭔가 잘 안 풀리는 상황도 자주 발생한다. 특히나 골드/퍼플 레이팅을 노릴 때 더욱 민감해질 수 밖에 없는 점인데, 이런 점들에 대한 대처가 부족한 것이 상당히 아쉽다. 

골드/퍼플 레이팅과 일부 재밌을만한 도전과제를 통해 게임의 추가적인 재미를 부여한 점은 인정할 만 하다. 특히 일부 도전과제는 같은 스테이지를 색다르게 접근해보게끔 만들어준다는 점이 마음에 든다. 하지만 골드/퍼플 레이팅은 미리 기준을 주지 않은 점이 상당히 아쉽게 느껴진다. 결국 이 부분마저도 플레이어가 게임을 플레이하면서 플레이어 스스로 고민해봐야 하는 점인데, 기사의 수/제한시간에 대한 기준을 줬으면 더 편하게 게임을 즐길 수 있었을 것이다.

기사의 희생과 그 희생을 바탕으로 풀어가는 게임성이 마음에 들었고 레벨 디자인도 준수하게 잘 되어있는 게임이다. 따라서 한 번 쯤 클리어해보긴 참 좋은 게임이다. 허나 깊게 파고들기에는 꽤나 버겁고 괴로운 게임이 될 것이다.

15887336.review:
[b]Note: video review embedded below.[/b]

I took me a long time to pin down exactly what it was that felt so strange about Life Goes On. I knew it wasn’t just the morbid nature of repurposing your corpses as puzzle solving tools, bizarre and unsettling as that is. And it wasn’t that there was something wrong with the puzzle themselves, because even with this odd feeling swirling around inside of me I was having a grand time solving them.

When I finally figured out what had been bugging me, it was both surprising and a little amusing. With how deeply the concept of death has been incorporated and mechanicalized in games, and then instilled in me through years of playing them, I realized Life Goes On felt off because it was doing precisely the opposite of what I’d been trained to do above all else: stay alive. With how many countless grotesquely violent and gore fill games I’ve played I’ve become rather horrifyingly numb to using violence as a mechanic against others, but through all of those keeping myself alive was always the objective above all else.

To do otherwise in most games is to effectively stop playing. Death is simply failure by another name, often meaningless but nearly always present and in some cases even romanticized as one of a game’s most notorious traits (Dark Souls being an obvious example). Life Goes On asked that I rethink the concept of death and in doing so it made it mean something again. Each time one of my knights died I felt an odd mixture of joy at being able to move forward, and distress at the very thought I was taking pleasure from leading my character to the slaughter.

What’s special about Life Goes On is that it doesn’t treat death the way so many modern games do. It’s not cynical, graphic, or intended to shock and appal you. It’s more like a cartoon where someone gets an anvil dropped on their head. Its situations are so absurd and everything drawn in such a delightfully cheerful tone, that I couldn’t take anything seriously because I wasn’t supposed to. Life Goes On recognizes how ridiculous its concept is and mostly manages to come off as silly, maybe even hilarious to some, rather than disturbing.

The way this unorthodox view of death is then applied to puzzle designs helps make a tired genre feel fresh again. There are a lot of the usual devices at work here, be they buttons, blocks, or various hazards, but the way you interact with them with the help of your past failures makes them feel original and inspired. Spikes become walkways, freezing beams create pushable blocks, and sticking yourself in an outlet completes the circuit opening the door. With death being directly integrated into the game design, it also helps take a lot of the edge off of missing a jump or screwing up a sequence, which removes most of the frustration so typical of the genre and had me playing through the entire game in just a few extended sittings.

I realize I’ve sort of come full circle with this review, beginning with how Life Goes On made me remember that death isn’t just a meaningless game of numbers, but then arriving back at how I enjoy its mechanical use here. Ultimately Life Goes On has its cake and eats it too, so any attempt to make it out to entirely subvert the usual violent video game trappings would be dubious at best. But that it made me consider all of this, with seemingly no intention and while delivering an excellent puzzle platformer, feels like at least a modest accomplishment. It got me thinking about things I never even recognize in most games, and though it didn’t quite go all the way, it started a discussion and even managed to have a lot of fun in the process. Odd praise to be sure, but it’s a rather odd game itself isn’t it.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TzvrAZ7k61g&ab_channel=MrNinjaSquirrel
[b]You can read more of my writing on [url=http://kritiqal.com/2015/05/18/life-goes-on-review/]Kritiqal[/url].[/b]

13974201.review:
Life Goes On charmed the living pants off me.  Which is weird to say about a game when you send knights to their horrible deaths by the dozen.  But the game revels in the comic, chaotic morbidity of it all, encouraging you to impale, electrocute, or incinerate your way to success.  Death isn't frustrating because it's too busy being comical - and half the time, it's bringing you closer and closer to your aims, even when it isn't necessarily intentional.  The mechanics are clearly (and subtly) explained, and the puzzles get just tricky enough toward the end that I felt like a boss overcoming them - without ever relying too heavily on skillful platforming or punishing the player for misjudgements (the error most physics-platformer games of this kind tend to make).

This game isn't just underrated, it's a quiet masterpiece.  It's tonally brilliant, earnestly funny, challenging (but not punishing) and good fun from first to last.  If you were looking for the really great, weird indie platformer nobody's ever heard of but is a blast to play - this is it.

13731709.review:
Who thinks of something like this? Who sits around a table and says, "Let's make a game where you use corpses to progress?" I mean, if you pitched it to me, I'd tell you it's a silly idea. But someone did it. And it works - quite well.

I am really enjoying Life Goes On. So far, I've spent around 3 hours with it, and I've finished a third of the game. You will finish it quicker, but I am a completionist so I'm trying to get the fewest deaths and the fastest times, and man, let me tell you it's not easy! 

The concept of the game is actually quite sound, and the execution is pretty good. In Life Goes On, you need the corpses of humorously, randomly named characters to succeed. It's not necessarily the corpses of your failures (although it certainly can AND WILL be...) - sometimes you need to strategically die to buzzsaws, spikes, and other such things to trigger traps and switches so you can open a door, turn off a flamethrower, get to a higher area, or just finish the level. 

The game only has one button - jump. (and of course, directional pad) There's no attack, or anything else. This doesn't get too boring though, because the graphics & music are quite nice. Also, the levels and challenges are varied enough that you aren't focused on the fact that you are just hitting jump the whole time. 

Speaking of levels and challenges, they are relatively easy to complete, but difficult to master. The levels are relatively short, most under a minute and a half, so you move through them pretty quickly, and they feel differing on the types of puzzles involved. There are three 'worlds' total. The game itself is pretty forgiving, because you have unlimited knights, but you can replay each level to try and get the best rating on both time, minimizing your deaths, and finding Jeff. 

Jeff. What do I say about Jeff? You'll meet this adorable looking fuzzball, wander over to pet him, and he'll eat you. Yup. You heard me. In every level. And just when you think you're safe... HE'S IN THE CREDITS TOO. Sorry. You'll have to learn to love Jeff. 

Don't forget about Jim. Who's Jim? Well, each time you die, the knight that spawns is randomly named (the name shows up at the bottom of the screen). Jim is quite prolific and has at least 40 family members (some variant of Jim or James), that have a random chance to spawn when you get a new knight. There's even an achievement for wiping them all out. Trust me, I'm working on it. Eventually, you'll take care of the problem at the source. There's an achievement for that too. 

All in all, I highly recommend Life Goes On and think that if you like puzzle or platforming games, this is a must-buy, even at regular price (which I feel is quite reasonable). My only complaint with the game is that it is quite short, and I would have liked to see more out of it. Regardless, it will not disappoint.

12277316.review:
To start: I used to add a header to these reviews, but since it often made the review too long to submit, I've opted to leave the header on my Backloggery.

Gameplay: It's no secret at this point; puzzle-platformers are a dime a dozen in the indie marketplace. I think that may have been because of Braid, but I'm not sure. Now, I'm not going to say that this game is necessarily revolutionary in how it handles the puzzle-platformer setup, but it does at least do things a little more interesting than the average block pushing puzzle, even though there are some of those in here. You see, what this game does differently is that this game wants you to die. A lot. Yet, this game isn't anywhere near on the level of challenge as something like Super Meat Boy. How does all this work, you may ask? Through jolly cooperation! Also, the character kinda looks like Solaire, so that really does help matters.

When you die, unless your corpse falls into a pit, it stays on the level. Ally corpses are the way to solve the puzzles in the game, as no puzzle (at least as far as I could tell) can be beaten with no deaths. Also, unlike a ton of other puzzle-platformers, this game strikes a perfect balance between puzzle and platformer (with the exception of one stage, Altered Trajectory which is both not a puzzle and the worst stage in the game IMO). Puzzles are fun to solve, and the platforming feels good. As for the controls, you run and jump. That's all you need, honestly.

For $12, this game does feel a bit short on content. Even going for 100% through the typical three-badge setup of these kinds of games (find hidden thing in level, beat it under par time, beat it with minimal deaths), this game only took me about four hours. Beyond that, I don't really see me playing this game all that much in the future. You can use your own price evaluations to determine how much this game is worth to you. A map editor would've been really nice,  but I think the same can be said for pretty much any puzzle-platformer. Apart from that, there really isn't much to talk about. It's a puzzle-platformer with some pretty nice level design that you can complete in one sitting pretty easily. Most of you will have gotten this from a Humble Bundle, as I did (the Humble Jumbo Bundle 2 IIRC?), so if you're looking for an opinion on this game, it's a good four or so hours. 9/10.

Story: As far as the storyline goes, there really isn't anything to talk about. You are hunting for the Holy Grail, and there is quite a lot of corpses along the way for some reason. This game definitely has a good sense of humor; a very British sense of humor, in fact. If you like things like Red Dwarf and Monty Python, you'll feel right at home here. It's very silly, and the concept of killing yourself to win the game doesn't really stop getting silly. If the level design wouldn't keep me coming back, the humor would. 9/10.

Graphics: A suprisingly good looking game for only being a ~200MB download. It's a very good blend of graphical fidelity and art style. Some of the levels do start to look a bit same-y, but considering that we're talking about the puzzle-platformer genre here, it's a considerable amount of praise to say that levels look a *bit* same-y. As for the technical aspects of this game, it fullscreens to your native resolution (a BIG plus in my books) on launch. Beyond that, there really isn't much else to tinker around with in the options menu as far as the graphical fidelity of the game goes. That's alright, though; the game never really phased my GTX 760, so I'd imagine most anyone with Intel HD Graphics at the very least would be able to run this game. Well optimized, it looks good, and it fullscreens to my native resolution. All the check boxes ticked for me. 5/5.

Sound: As always, there's two major things to talk about here: the soundtrack and the voice acting. The voice acting really only consist of death knells, which are as you would most likely infer by this point in reading this review, very silly. As for the soundtrack, some of the tracks are forgettable, but for the most part I'd say it's an above-average medieval-inspired orchestral soundtrack. It's fitting, but I'd probably never listen to it outside of the game. Just not my thing. There were a few strange audio glitches in which tracks would either layer over eachother in a really annoying way or just not play at all for a while. It didn't happen too often, though, so it's not too big of a worry. Anyways, the voice acting is silly, the OST is good but not too memorable, and the sound only bugs out once in a while. 4/5.

Overall scores are: 9/9/5/4; cumulative score of 9.0/10. Again, your mileage may vary on the game's value. I'd personally wait for a sale before I would pick up this game, but if you're not strapped for cash or anything, $12 is a perfectly fine value. It's a better value than AAA games, that's for damn sure.

10863238.review:
As the trailer suggests, this game is a humorous cross between puzzle platformer and lemmings, where you take advantage of the deaths of your predecessors to progress through the different levels.

With an unlimited number of knights at your disposal, you control one until it dies, then another, and so on, and on each try to die in a way that your corpse will be of some benefit to your next knight. But doing well at a level means using fewer knights (wouldn't want them to die in vain, right? ;)

Progressing in the game uses more of your puzzle skills than your platforming skills, and for considering you will only be using 3-4 buttons, the game gets surprisingly complex.

Completing the various levels and achievements feels reasonably satisfying, and it can be amusing to overcome any obstacle by throwing numerous knights at it in various ways.

The game contains several references to other games, most of which I found quite amusing, but more than anything else I found myself laughing out loud at many of the messages describing how varyingly successful I had been at the end of each level.

Detto ciò, e tolto questo sassolino dalla scarpa, Life Goes On si presenta come un puzzle game piuttosto ben congeniato che, purtroppo, inizierà a offrire una sfida intellettiva solo da metà gioco in poi. I quadri che dovremo affrontare utilizzeranno tutta una serie di classici cliché (seppur ben mescolati) tra la fisica dei corpi, fiamme, spuntoni e catapulte per portare a casa la coppa finale. A rendere il tutto più stuzzicante intervengono i “limiti” (relativi — non vedrete mai la scritta di game over) di tempo e vite imposti dagli sviluppatori per migliorare la propria prestazione, oltre all’amico Jeff da raggiungere come bonus nascosto (anche qui, poche volte è realmente invisibile a una prima occhiata). Il sistema funziona, e sarà necessario capire quali sono i corretti passaggi da fare, o meglio, le corrette morti da compiere per poter avere la strada spianata fino alla Coppa finale. Eppure… qualcosa manca. 
L’intero Life Goes On in fondo potrebbe essere considerato come un mobile game qualsiasi, sia per la semplicità di utilizzo, sia per la pochezza di dettagli dei suoi comparti. Dei brani d’accompagnamento ben riusciti, una grafica caricaturale e nessun filo narrativo sono ciò che ci aspetterà al di là del mero gameplay che, ripetiamo, tutto sommato è stato compiuto con rigore. Anche la trovata di assegnare un nome casuale sempre diverso al protagonista (un cavaliere uomo o donna, con la simpatica trovata della dinastia Jim da eliminare) farà sorridere per le prime volte, spingendovi a dimenticarvi del tutto della chicca dopo le prime morti. Insomma, un puzzle game basilare, semplice, ma che non riesce ad andare oltre alla sua prova tecnica, perdendo quasi subito interesse nella sua trovata che non è stata ben sfruttata.

Vieni a leggere la recensione completa su TheShelterNetwork.com:

10056614.review:
Death. It has always been something that is best avoided in video games. Also real life would be the other main place. But as Life Goes On, an indie puzzle game by Infinite Monkeys shows, sometimes it can be used to solve environmental physics based puzzles.

The hook of this game is a little tricky to wrap your head around, but simple to understand once you see it in action. Basically you control an infinite number of little knights and want to get them to the golden chalice at the end of each level. To do so, you can respawn a knight whenever a death occurs and make use of the previous body to further your cause. For example, you might be faced with a spike pit which is too wide to jump over. In this case, simply jump a knight into the middle of it, respawn and use the lifeless body as a stepping stone to get to the other side (The game gives each character a name, but you'll never bother to read it).

It is a base mechanics that works extremely well. If you played the demo (and you should) you would quickly have got into the swing of using your minions to get a little bit further each life. It is clever and the initial levels make great use of the different possibilities the mechanic presents. Unfortunately, like a lot of clever ideas it runs out of steam far too quickly.

Life Goes on just doesn't have enough good variety to maintain your attention. By the end of the first set of levels you will have had your fill of the different types of puzzles and so it is a let down that the next set is more or less repeating things all over again. The levels get longer and the challenges more difficult, but really the game is just chaining the same challenges you have already faced over and over again into growing chunks. Worse, whenever a new mechanic is introduced, it tends to lean more towards frustration rather than fun, especially when compared to the very solid base (trying to avoid activating respawn points is never a fun time).

To be fair, although the 3rd "world" on drags a lot, there are still a couple of memorable stages here and there. One in particular pays homage to a popular steam themed game and the "final level" in each group represents somewhat of a boss battle, that is much more fun to play through. If only these levels had been the norm, rather than the exception this review would be a lot more glowing. As it stands the game only shows glimpses of potential and innovation, perhaps a lesson for the developers next game (quality of puzzles over quantity please!).

Mixing it up is the set challenge of beating the clock and set number of deaths for each level. You will also have a "fuzzy" creature to find in each level which will eat one of your knights. While this promises diversity, the reality is it just means you are beating the level three times with a slightly different focus. Sadly there doesn't appear to be much scope for earning all three in one run consistently and there is seemingly no payoff for doing so anyway.

The rest of the package is well put together. The graphics are functional and the sound and music is nicely done. The menus work, but are a little uninspired (think ios style) and there is basically no story to drive you on. The environments are nice though and have a lot of good touches such as moving power cables. There isn't a lot of variety in the caverns, but later levels do at least provide a slightly different colour palette.

In terms of gameplay, the knights themselves are perhaps a little inconsistent as platforms (you'll often try to jump on one and "miss") but this isn't something you can't adjust and plan for and there is a very low penalty for failure. The controls in general are tight and it is nice that the game automatically "grabs" you onto other knights so this is nowhere near as fiddly as it might have been.

Is there enough content for the asking price? I'd still suggest that there is, at a push, but it is walking a very fine line (looking at 4-5 hours I would think). The base game here is so solid that I highly recommend everybody tries it, but the lack of ideas means even the demo might just be sufficient (or waiting for a deeper sale might be the best option).

So ultimately a bit of a disappointment despite still being a solid game. But then, life always goes on.

9921777.review:
[url=http://finalstage.es/analisis-life-goes-on/] Final Stage Review[/url]

Seguro que muchos de vosotros habéis soñado alguna vez con ser un caballero medieval en busca de aventuras. Pero seguro que a muy pocos les hará gracia morir en el intento. Pues ese es el espíriu de este gamberro título para PC: Life Goes On.

ANÁLISIS LIFE GOES ON

Se trata de un juego indie que podéis encontrar en Steam, cargado de un sentido del humor un tanto negro pero que es divertido como pocos. El objetivo del juego será completar una serie de niveles de desarrollo en 2D superando toda una serie de obstáculos y puzzles en el menor tiempo posible. El juego parace muy influenciado por Rayman o los Lemmings, incluso en el diseño de los personajes.

Jugabilidad

Entonces, ¿Qué aporta de nuevo? Pues que al igual que en los Lemmings la cooperación entre personajes es crucial. Solo que aquí solo podran ayudarte cuando hayan pasado a mejor vida. Cada uno de los caballeros (que tendrán nombre, apellidos e incluso un título nobiliario) deberá morir para abrir un camino a sus sucesor y que este pueda alcanzar la gloria. Para lograr este objetivo iremos activando una serie de portales que nos servirán de punto de Check Point.

Esta ayuda postuma puede ser mediante bloquear ciertos obstaculos, como pinchos, o activar interruptores, que pueden abrir puertas, activar trampas etc. Los niveles más divertidos son los de final de fase, ya que tendremos que poner a prueba nuestra habilidad para poder superar unos niveles que podemos catalogar como “Final Bosses”.

El objetivo en cada nivel será completarlo en el menor tiempo posible, y perdiendo cuantos menos caballeros sea posible en el proceso. A partir de cierto punto se unirá un reto extra, que será alimentar a unos bichos peludos que encontraremos en puntos complicados del juego. Una gran pega que tiene la jugabilidad es la no existencia de un límite de muertes, por lo que sólo será cuestión de tiempo y paciencia el acabarlo, sin que exista una posibilidad real de perder.

Gráficos

Al decir que el juego se ve muy influenciado por Rayman no nos referiamos únicamente a la jugabilidad. Los personajes, que pese a tener nombres propios, lucen exactamente iguales tienen el mismo cuerpo que el personaje de Ubisoft: carecen de brazos o piernas, teniendo sólo manos y pies.

En cuanto a los gráficos de los niveles, van variando, manteniéndose siempre fieles a la ambientación de cada una de las fases, pero puede llegar a hacerse monótono con el tiempo. Lo mismo ocurre con los elementos como los obstáculos y los interruptores, que no variaran de una fase a otra, siendo siempre los mismos.

Sonido

No se trata de un apartado muy desarrollado en el juego, ya que los personajes son mudos, y solo podremos oir sus expresiones. Los sonidos al impactar, ser devorados o morir son bastante divertidos y nada realistas, lo que ayuda a que no nos sintamos mal por la perdida de tantos buenos caballeros.

En cuanto a la música, tiene un esquema muy simple, pero ayuda a concentrarse, especialmente en los puzzles más difíciles. Sin embargo no goza de gran variedad, por lo que tras pasadas varias horas jugando, se nos queda grabada en la cabeza y no podemos olvidarla.
Conclusión

Se trata de un juego realmente entretendo para pasar esos ratos que no sabes qué hacer. No revoluciona ningún género, pero si le aporta una nueva visión más macabra, pero igual de divertida.

9917628.review:
Life Goes On reminded me a bit of The Swapper but instead of creating clones you're creating dead clones. See the resemblance ? Well, they're clones, but not in a traditional way. Each knight is given a random name to make you think you're dealing with other persons here. But they don't fool me. It would've been nice if every now and then a knight would get different equipment. Then, and only then, will I get the illusion that I'm dealing with different persons here. But it's not important, so let's just drop it.

Anyway, you have to use your dead clones to make it past the levels. See spikes but can't cross ? Just jump in the middle of it and you'll be able to jump on that guy's head with another knight. The game starts with basic puzzle platforming but halfway through becomes more difficult when it throws other puzzle elements your way. It never becomes frustratingly difficult, as long as you pay attention. I got stuck in a level or two and in hindsight they were actually very obvious. So it also depends on the person eventually. The game isn't very long and you should be able to finish it in 2-3 hours max, depending on if you want to earn all of the available medals.

The graphics aren't great, they are actually pretty simple but they get the job done. I personally thought it lacked a bit of personality. The voice acting is also very basic, with only a scream whenever a knight dies. The music on the other hand is better than expected and I enjoyed it very much.

The last 2 levels of the game (the true last level and the credits level) are the most impressive levels and it's unfortunate that the other levels are so static in comparison (even if some of the puzzles are harder). If there ever will be a sequel I sincerely hope they'll make use of more platforming, just like those last 2 levels. Or maybe a combination of both, who knows ?

Life Goes On is an enjoyable puzzle game and if you liked The Swapper I'm pretty certain you'll have fun playing this one, too.

[Rating: 75/100]

9857164.review:
I first played the demo months ago and instantly fell in love with this game.
The full game did not fail to deliver.

The whole concept of (literally) standing on the shoulders of those who came before is presented wonderfully. See a deathtrap? Die on it, then respawn and walk on your corpse. Switch that has to be held down? Die so that your corpse falls on it, then respawn and walk past. Et cetera, et cetera.

The controls are a bit inaccurate at times, and will most likely leave you dying slightly more often than intended. Although since this game is all about sacrificing one knight to make a path for another, a few more corpses lying around aren't that much of a problem. (And if you're finding it difficult, a few more corpses aren't a problem at all.)
The puzzles are challenging but not frustrating, and make great use of switches, platforms, corpses, and checkpoints. The solution is always there, if you know where to look.
The music is unintrusive, yet amazing. It fits perfectly into the game. The sound design, too, is brilliant. Everything just works together really well.
There is tremendous replay value in this game, too. Times (and deaths) to beat, secrets to find, more knights to sacrifice... And if you want a quick game (or want to prune Jim's family tree further), there are no lengthy menus to keep you from killing knights. This is evident even in the demo. Ten minutes worth of content, and I had over an hour logged.
There's also a great (if morbid) sense of humour present. The knights' death cries are hilarious, the names are generally overblown (and if they're not, it's funnier), and the victory screens... well, "VICTORY is failure rounded up!" is just one of the possible messages to recieve upon finishing a level. And then there's the credits of the demo.

If you haven't played the demo yet, you should. Even if you know you want this game. The credits alone are worth it. Possibly the title screen as well. And if you're undecided, the demo is basically a slightly earlier version with less levels and slightly different graphics (mostly just checkpoints and the victory screen are different, really).

Full review available at: https://www.youtube.com/BrbteabreakTV http://youtu.be/VwalWvJA0cs

Puzzle platformer is a genre which the indie scene has taken up whole heartedly. It’s a heavily saturated market and because of this you need a stand out feature or gimmick in order to be successful. We’ve seen water manipulation, magnetism and some even let you wind back the clock. Life Goes On has chosen to use dead knights as its “gimmick”, using them as a platforming and puzzle solving tool. The problem is instead of using them as a standout feature and allowing for amazing puzzle design, it’s there for no more than a quick chuckle.

9842052.review:
Full Video Review here - http://youtu.be/klkodOS-ZCI

An Indie platform puzzler that puts the mass in massacre. The game was developed by Infinite Monkeys Entertainment and was originally conceived at the 2012 Global Game Jam. The main aim of each level is to reach the golden cup, the holy grail so to speak. How do you do this with all the death traps you ask? Well its easy when your a king, with a portal and have an infinite number of knights to send to their deaths until you can accomplish your goal.

In Life Goes On, if you die that's not the end, instead you just send another knight through the spawn portal. This is not just a piece of gimmicky morbid comedy, it is in fact a core mechanic of the game. Sometimes having to sacrifice your minions is required to progress or solve a puzzle. An example of this is if the objective is across a floor of spikes, lay down the lives of your knights so one can climb across the hole ridden bodies to reach the grail.

In other platformers, you sole objective would be to avoid a deadly trap however in Life goes on, you may need to use that trap to accomplish your goal, perhaps you need to sacrifice a knight on a saw blade to strategically land the body on a button or build a mound of bodies to reach a ledge. What this means is that obstacles in Life Goes On are not just obstacles they become useful tools to use to progress.

Overall Life Goes On is certainly a good platformer that provides a mix of enjoyment, comedy and challenge. The game provides a unique twist and this twist provides great synergy of the level design and mechanics. For anyone who loves the genre it will certainly cure that puzzler platformer itch. Don't forget to check out the full review!
